subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: Taking these one by one: 1) The CMU Dictionary has multiple entries, for example: IMPLEMENTING  IH1 M P L AH0 M EH2 N T IH0 NG IMPLEMENTING(2)  IH1 M P L AH0 M
messageBody:
Taking these one by one:

1) The CMU Dictionary has multiple entries, for example:

IMPLEMENTING IH1 M P L AH0 M EH2 N T IH0 NG
IMPLEMENTING(2) IH1 M P L AH0 M EH2 N IH0 NG

The first entry is *much* more common in the US. The 'T' needs to be
included in a standard spelling.

2) The 'H' needs to be there. Again, we should use the first entry in
the dictionary:

HUMAN HH Y UW1 M AH0 N
HUMAN(2) Y UW1 M AH0 N

3) Such cases (rules for condensing QS spelling) can easily be handled
programatically, but let's not get ahead of ourselves.

Skipping ahead to your comments on Hangul, have you heard of Engul?
Check it out:
http://www.omniglot.com/writing/engul.htm

Ted





On Nov 15, 2007 4:11 PM, Anthony Hagan <anthonydh@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...>
>
> wrote:
> > If you have suggestions on word choice (and this applies to
> anyone), and
> > you want to make a change, just send me a text file with the TO
> word on
> > the left, followed by some space, followed by the QS word in ASCII.
> For
> > example:
> >
> > grass grAs
> > birdfeeder bardfIdar
> >
> > The more people that submit corrected words, the more accurate the
> > dictionary and the news.
> >
> > Paul
> >
>
> Paul,
>
> I'm happy to send you some dictionary updates. But I'd like to make
> sure I'm sending you the right sort of updates: as I don't speak
> American English, I don't want to send you material which doesn't fit
> into an American dictionary. (For this reason I'll stay clear of
> sending vowel changes!)
>
> Here are some questions for you:
>
> 1. Cases of Dropped #3Tea.
> As I said in post 1467, I don't like the dropped #3Tea in many QS
> news words. An example is "implementing" which was converted
> to ...#28Et-#23No-#26It-#21iNG. Should we put the #3Tea in (to
> get ...#28Et-#23No-#3Tea-#26It-#21iNG), or is the dropped #3Tea a
> widespread Americanism which should remain?
>
> (Cases of dropped tea - are we revisiting the Boston Tea Party?)
>
> 1. Cases of Dropped #19He.
> "Human" was transcribed as #17Ye-#40OOze-#22May-#36Utter-#23No.
> Should this be #19He-#17Ye-#40OOze... or H-dropping the norm in
> America?
>
> 2. Quickscript manual abbreviations
> Should we implement QS manual abbreviations, such as #21iNG (instead
> of -#26It-#21iNG) for the gerund-participle suffix "ing"? Do you
> want to do these one-by-one, or leave them for you to do a global
> update at some point?
>
> 3. Naming dot
> Which character should we use for a naming dot in a text file? Just
> a standard ".", or something else?
>
> 4. File format
> DO you want DOS or Unix format files? CR-LF, or just LF?
>
> One area I can certainly help in the dictionary is Korean names. (An
> obscure topic, but there have been a few Korean stories in the QS
> news.) I learnt a little bit of Korean - enough to know that TO
> transcriptions of Korean names can be misleading. In QS we can do
> better!
>
> (Off topic, but the Korean alphabet, Hangul, was designed in the 15th
> century to reflect the actual sounds of Korean. It's a brilliant
> piece of work, and many of the letters actually resemble the way the
> letter is articulated in the mouth. So when I first came across
> Quickscript, the similarities to Hangul were striking.)
>
> Cheers, Anthony DH
>
>
>
